title: Sentence Level Sentiment Analysis
text: Text analysis enables the identification and extraction of sentiment information from text. By leveraging tools such as asent, sentimentr, and basic sentiment lexicons, it is possible to construct a sentiment classifier that can estimate whether the underlying sentiment of a given text is positive, negative, or neutral.

title: Sentence Level Sentiment Analysis
text:
from OOP to FP
Python is an object-oriented programming (OOP) language, and it is possible to convert Python classes into functions in R, which mainly support functional programming (FP).

Codespacy <- reticulate::import("spacy") # load spacy

asent <- reticulate::import("asent") # load asent

nlp <- spacy$load("en_core_web_lg") # load pre-trained model

nlp$add_pipe("asent_en_v1") # add asent pipe

<asent.component.Asent object at 0x000002306EFBD5E0>

Codenlp_safe <- possibly(.f = nlp, otherwise = "error!") # error handling

get_polarity <- nlp_safe("sentiment")$get_extension("polarity")[[3]] # load python function

get_sentiment_asent <- \(x) {
    result <- nlp_safe(x) %>%
        get_polarity() %>%
        print() %>%
        capture.output() %>%
        str_extract_all("-?0\\.\\d+") %>%
        unlist() %>%
        as.numeric()

    names(result) <- c("neg", "neu", "pos", "compound")

    return(result)
}
